one_paragraph_summary: During this short observation admission, a middle-aged woman with advanced AIDS and ESRD on hemodialysis presented from home after dialysis with acute lightheadedness, weakness, and one episode of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting, without fever or focal infectious symptoms. Initial ED vitals showed hypotension that improved with IV fluids; she received empiric piperacillin–tazobactam and vancomycin due to concern for sepsis in an immunocompromised host, but chest radiograph was clear and blood cultures remained negative, so antibiotics were discontinued. Her history revealed that pregabalin (Lyrica) had been started two days prior for chronic right V1 post-herpetic neuralgia, with a prior similar intolerance to gabapentin. Given the temporal association and lack of infectious source, her lightheadedness and weakness were attributed to a medication side effect of pregabalin, exacerbated by ESRD and post-dialysis hypotension. Lyrica was stopped, and her symptoms improved. She continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis in hospital, with management of hyperkalemia (K 6.5 mEq/L) and uremia, and received cinacalcet, sevelamer, doxercalciferol, and heparin per dialysis protocol. Her chronic AIDS prophylaxis with azithromycin and TMP-SMX was continued, while full antiretroviral therapy was deferred to outpatient management. For neuropathic pain, she was started on low-dose duloxetine three times weekly post-dialysis. She remained hemodynamically stable at her baseline low pressures, with improved lightheadedness and no new infectious signs, and was discharged home with services on her chronic dialysis schedule and updated medications.

problem_list.status_at_discharge: Presented with sudden onset of lightheadedness, subjective weakness, and mild vertigo-like sensation after an otherwise uneventful hemodialysis session, associated with one episode of non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting and low blood pressures below her usual post-dialysis baseline. Infectious workup including chest X-ray and blood cultures was negative, and she remained afebrile without localizing symptoms. Symptoms were attributed to a side effect of recently started pregabalin (Lyrica), especially given prior similar intolerance to gabapentin and underlying ESRD. Lyrica was discontinued on admission, IV fluids were given, and empiric antibiotics were stopped once sepsis was deemed unlikely. Orthostatic vitals were negative, and by discharge her lightheadedness and weakness had significantly improved.

She has ESRD due to HIV-associated nephropathy and is anuric on chronic thrice-weekly hemodialysis via a tunneled left common femoral vein catheter. During this admission she underwent in-hospital hemodialysis without major complication. Pre-dialysis labs showed elevated creatinine (8.1 mg/dL), BUN (52 mg/dL), hyperphosphatemia (5.1 mg/dL), and hyperkalemia (6.5 mEq/L), which were managed with dialysis and standard dialysis medications including cinacalcet, sevelamer, doxercalciferol, and heparin for circuit anticoagulation and catheter dwell. Her blood pressure, though chronically low post-dialysis, stabilized with cautious fluid management. She was discharged dialysis-dependent, to continue her usual Monday/Wednesday/Friday schedule and renal medications, with cinacalcet dose reduced to 30 mg daily.

problem_list.problem: Advanced HIV/AIDS with opportunistic infection prophylaxis and low health literacy
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has longstanding HIV/AIDS with a very low CD4 count and high viral load prior to this admission, with history of opportunistic infections including Pneumocystis pneumonia. At the time of admission she was not taking antiretroviral therapy, though she had recently received blister packs with HIV medications but had not started them due to confusion and low health literacy. During hospitalization she was continued on Pneumocystis prophylaxis with TMP-SMX DS three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg weekly. The team reconciled her medications based on chart review, recognized her difficulty understanding her regimen, and recommended outpatient follow-up with her HIV specialist and a pharmacist for medication teaching and to restart ART safely after discharge.

problem_list.problem: Right V1 post-herpetic neuralgia and chronic headache
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has chronic right V1 distribution pain and headache following prior herpes zoster with nervous system complications and decreased vision in the right eye. Pregabalin was started two days before admission for this neuropathic pain but was discontinued due to suspected adverse effects causing dizziness and weakness. Given the severity of her neuropathic pain and its impact on quality of life, she was started on low-dose duloxetine 20 mg three times weekly after hemodialysis, in coordination with her outpatient providers. She was also discharged with acetaminophen as needed for pain. At discharge, her chronic pain persisted but was manageable, and she was instructed to monitor for duloxetine side effects.

Admission and discharge labs showed chronic macrocytic anemia (Hgb 10.4–11.4 g/dL, MCV 104 fL), leukopenia (WBC 2.4–3.3 K/uL), and thrombocytopenia (platelets 105–128 K/uL), with mild RDW elevation and marked eosinophilia (14.6%). Coagulation studies (PT, INR, PTT) were normal. These cytopenias and eosinophilia were known chronic issues in the setting of advanced HIV and prior workup by infectious disease, with consideration of parasitic etiologies such as strongyloides, but no acute intervention was undertaken during this admission. Counts remained low but stable, and there were no bleeding events or transfusions.

She has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and was in sinus rhythm during this admission. She was not anticoagulated, consistent with prior management, and remained on aspirin 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis. No sustained arrhythmias or hemodynamic instability related to atrial fibrillation were documented during this stay.

She endorsed depressed mood without active suicidal ideation. Psychiatry evaluated her and recommended outpatient psychiatric follow-up. No new antidepressant was started specifically for mood during this admission, though duloxetine was initiated primarily for neuropathic pain and may have ancillary mood benefits. She was discharged with instructions to establish care with an outpatient psychiatrist.

key_tests_and_results.test: Initial laboratory evaluation (CBC, BMP, coagulation, liver panel)
key_tests_and_results.result: On admission, labs showed leukopenia (WBC 2.4 K/uL), macrocytic anemia (Hgb 11.4 g/dL, Hct 35.4%, MCV 104 fL, MCH 33.4 pg), thrombocytopenia (platelets 105 K/uL), normal PT/INR and PTT, normal liver enzymes and bilirubin, creatinine 5.9 mg/dL, BUN 36 mg/dL, potassium 5.0 mEq/L, sodium 141 mEq/L, bicarbonate 24 mEq/L, anion gap 17, phosphate 4.2 mg/dL, calcium 10.1 mg/dL, and LDH 237 IU/L. Differential showed eosinophilia at 14.6%.

Frontal and lateral chest X-ray showed normal heart size and cardiomediastinal contours, slightly decreased lung volumes with no focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax. A large-bore inferior approach dialysis catheter was seen terminating in the right atrium. Overall, no acute cardiopulmonary process.
Peripheral blood cultures obtained on admission showed no growth, arguing against bacteremia or sepsis as a cause of her hypotension and symptoms.

key_tests_and_results.test: Follow-up labs prior to in-hospital hemodialysis
key_tests_and_results.result: On Hospital Day 2, pre-dialysis labs showed worsening renal function and electrolyte abnormalities: creatinine 8.1 mg/dL, BUN 52 mg/dL, potassium 6.5 mEq/L, phosphate 5.1 mg/dL, sodium 139 mEq/L, chloride 104 mEq/L, bicarbonate 22 mEq/L, anion gap 20, calcium 9.6 mg/dL. CBC showed WBC 3.3 K/uL, Hgb 10.4 g/dL, Hct 31.9%, MCV 104 fL, platelets 128 K/uL. Lactate was 1.9 mmol/L. These findings prompted in-hospital hemodialysis.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Empiric sepsis management with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
treatments_and_meds.details: On presentation with hypotension and systemic symptoms in the setting of advanced immunosuppression, she received IV normal saline boluses (total approximately 1.5 L) and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics including piperacillin–tazobactam and vancomycin. Blood cultures and chest radiograph were obtained. As her blood pressure improved, she remained afebrile, chest X-ray showed no acute process, and blood cultures remained negative, antibiotics were discontinued within the first hospital day.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Discontinuation of pregabalin (Lyrica) and initiation of duloxetine for neuropathic pain
treatments_and_meds.details: Given the close temporal relationship between starting pregabalin (Lyrica) for right V1 post-herpetic neuralgia and the onset of lightheadedness, weakness, and dizziness, and her prior similar reaction to gabapentin, Lyrica was identified as the most likely cause of her acute symptoms and was stopped on admission. After discussion with her outpatient providers, she was started on duloxetine 20 mg orally three times a week after hemodialysis as an alternative agent for neuropathic pain, with counseling to monitor for side effects. She was discharged on duloxetine and instructed never to restart Lyrica.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: In-hospital hemodialysis and ESRD medication management
treatments_and_meds.details: She continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis during the admission, including an in-hospital session on Hospital Day 2 in response to rising creatinine (8.1 mg/dL), BUN (52 mg/dL), hyperkalemia (6.5 mEq/L), and hyperphosphatemia (5.1 mg/dL). Dialysis was performed with standard anticoagulation using IV heparin and heparin dwell for the catheter, and she received IV doxercalciferol for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Her phosphate binder sevelamer carbonate 1600 mg three times daily with meals and cinacalcet were continued, with cinacalcet dose adjusted from 60 mg to 30 mg daily. Post-dialysis, her electrolytes and uremic parameters improved and blood pressure stabilized at her baseline low range.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: HIV opportunistic infection prophylaxis and deferred ART restart
treatments_and_meds.details: During hospitalization she was maintained on Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim DS one tablet three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg once weekly. She was not on active antiretroviral therapy at the time of admission, despite having received blister packs with ART medications, due to confusion and low health literacy. The inpatient team reconciled her medications and encouraged her to work with her outpatient HIV specialist to restart ART after discharge, while continuing prophylactic regimens.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Symptomatic management of pain, pruritus, and nausea
treatments_and_meds.details: Her chronic right V1 neuralgia and headache were managed with acetaminophen 650 mg as needed and oxycodone 5 mg as needed for more severe pain. Hydroxyzine 25 mg three times daily as needed was used for diffuse pruritus related to her chronic skin disease and ESRD. Ondansetron 4 mg IV as needed was available for nausea, though she had only one vomiting episode prior to admission. These measures provided symptomatic relief without recurrence of severe dizziness once pregabalin was stopped.

Given her history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and absence of sustained arrhythmias during this admission, she was continued on aspirin 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis without initiation of systemic anticoagulation, consistent with prior outpatient management.
